Changes.LogName: Strings for PM's new Outdoor Map

Entries.{{OutdoorStrings}}.000: A marble statue depiciting a conventionally attractive woman. You wonder if it reflects the owner's tastes.
Entries.{{OutdoorStrings}}.002: Pei Ming seems to have locked the door for you and doesn't want you to enter his house anymore.

Changes.LogName: Strings for PM's new Indoor Map

Entries.PeiMingHouse.000: You wish you had never seen what's inside that drawer.
Entries.PeiMingHouse.001: Those look like strategic notes... or, wait? Is that a... poem?
Entries.PeiMingHouse.002: You wonder why Pei Ming has a kitchen at all. He can neither cook nor does he like doing it, but expects women to be perfect cooks. Perhaps you should teach him a lesson someday.
Entries.PeiMingHouse.003: Pei Ming seems to be fond of roses.
Entries.PeiMingHouse.004: A good book and tea gets you through the gloomiest day. Even Pei Ming seems to understand that. You check the book cover and read the title 'Heaven Official's Blessing'.
Entries.PeiMingHouse.005: An interesting collection of trinkets and artifacts that seem as if they were from a whole different world. It appears that they manifested here just as randomly as Pei Ming did.
Entries.PeiMingHouse.006: Pei Ming appears to enjoy wine. This bottle looks very expensive...
Entries.PeiMingHouse.007: Different kinds of robes that are befitting of an ancient deity. Pei Ming really sticks out like a sore thumb here.
Entries.PeiMingHouse.008: Fresh and cheap?... there is something written in the bottom left corner of the flag. 'Happy birthday from your two best friends, old Pei.'
Entries.PeiMingHouse.009: You always find a freshly brewed mug of tea here. You would never find him drink tea from those cheap tea bags.

Entries.PeiMingSpouseRoom.000: Pei Ming deposited books of all genres for indoor days here.
Entries.PeiMingSpouseRoom.001: Since Pei Ming loves roses so much, he put some on display here.
Entries.PeiMingSpouseRoom.002: Pei Ming's favorite wine. Maybe you should have a drink with him together later.
